it says version 1:4.1p1-7ubuntu4.1 of the client is going to be installed, but myself i have version 1:4.1p1-7ubuntu4 (the one it wants). so i suppose you might have some third-party repositories in your /etc/apt/sources.list that provider a newer openssh-client (and you might have that one installed as well)
try "apt-cache policy openssh-client", see what's installed - if anything - and where it came from
if you actually have that wrong version of openssh-client installed, remove it using "apt-cache --purge remove openssh-client", then reinstall it after your repositories are good
uuh, know what? it isn't quite clear to me where that version came from. looks like you had installed it manually using dpkg...?
try just removing it (using the command i said, not just remove) and reinstalling
actually - remove it, issue a "sudo apt-get clean", and reinstall
just type "sudo apt-get clean" and thats it? (no arguments)
yes, that will clean your APT cache, so that it will not try to reuse the same package
i'd say just try to reinstall first. though, sooner or later, i suppose you really should fix your repositories
i have no experience with synaptic at all, i use aptitude exclusively
no, "sudo apt-get update ; sudo apt-get dist-upgrade"
(or make that "sudo aptitude dist-upgrade", if you prefer aptitude. i do)
what's the difference between update and dist-upgrade?
update fetches the list of packages (including any changes). dist-upgrade actually installs the new versions
